Copy.Pstm24:
Can you believe your baby is two?

The last two years have probably flown by in a flash, leaving you with lots of happy memories - and a two year old! You and your little one have come a long way in the last two years, so you deserve a celebration. Enjoy it!

Your toddler may now be able to run, catch a ball and speak in short sentences. If you're lucky, he or she will also sleep through the night most of the time. Find out what else to expect from your two year old here.

If you are thinking about potty training soon, check out our tips for success. Start talking about it before you begin so your little one gets used to the idea and be prepared for accidents!
Copy.Pstm25:
Listening to your toddler.

This month, we've got advice on getting your toddlers attention and getting them to listen. It is also good practice to be a good listener yourself as you are your toddler's best role model.

We've also got some top tips for mealtimes to try and make them as stress free as possible.
Copy.Pstm26:
Teach your child to keep their cool.

If your child sometimes turns into a terror, check out our guide to spotting the signs of a tantrum so you can nip it in the bud. Much less stress for you and your little one.

At this age, they may also get frustrated when things don't go their way when they are playing, such as that huge tower block they are trying to build taking a topple. See if they can work out what went wrong themselves as this is great for their reasoning and problem-solving skills.

You can also encourage them to use their imagination at this age which is good for their development and great fun for you to join in too! And if you have noticed your child copying you more than ever now, encourage them by letting them help whenever you can - dusting is much more fun for a toddler than it is for you!
Copy.Pstm27:
What to do when your toddler swears.

Unless you're very careful, chances are your toddler will overhear (and copy!) the odd rude word here and there - it might be from you, your partner or even on television. Regardless, you can guarantee he or she will use their satisfying new word in public, leaving you red-faced with embarrassment or struggling not to laugh. It's good to set the boundaries with little one's too so they understand what is right and wrong.

Also this month, brush up on your first aid skills. Plus, stay on top of your finances with our 10 ways to boost your income.
Copy.Pstm28: Reading to your toddler is a great way of bonding with your little one and enjoying quality time together. It's also good for your child - research shows that reading and encouraging listening skills helps children perform better at school and teaches them to express themselves more confidently and clearly. Find out more about why reading matters and how to read to your child.
Copy.Pstm29:
If you'd like a holiday but you can't face flying with a toddler, why not try camping? It's cheap, surprisingly easy, and popular with children of all ages, come rain or shine. We've got a guide to camping with kids, plus some top tips to help you survive the experience.

If your child loves vegetables, you are very lucky! But if you have a fussy little eater that doesn't like their greens, we have some tips on sneaking them into their food without them knowing!

We've also got a handy step-by-step guide for potty training this week to make the transition from nappies to grown-up pants a doddle. Some children crack it within days but most take a bit longer so stick to it and soon your little one will be nappy free day and night.
Copy.Pstm30:
Your little one is growing each and everyday and becoming their own independent little person. They may be picking up new words every day and wowing you by putting words together. Find out more about how you can help your little one's development here.

Sometimes it can seem as if the world is geared up for mum, dad and 2.4 children. But the number of one-child families is on the increase and there are many reasons families have one child. If that sounds like you, here's why having an only child is great.
Copy.Pstm31:
Some children take to potty training right away, but for many, it's not so straightforward. If your child isn't getting the hang of it, check out our potty training tips for some extra advice. Remember, lots of children are still in nappies for a while yet, so it may just be that your toddler's not ready.

It may seem a while off, but pre-school is only round the corner for your little one so it is important that you choose the right school that works for you both.

Your little one is probably eating the same food as you now but it's important to ensure that they are getting all the nutrition they need for their growing bodies. Check out our guide for tips on getting the balance right.
Copy.Pstm32:
It's good to refresh your first aid knowledge regularly. Hopefully you'll never have to use it, but just in case, here's our guide to dealing with cuts, burns and other mishaps. We've also got information about preschool immunisations that your child will need over the next few years.

If potty training hasn't gone to plan yet, we've got lots of tips that will help you to train your little boy or little girl.

Helping your child to development through music is great for their language skills and it is even suggested that it improves their IQ. So what are you waiting for, get the xylophone and drums out (and maybe some earplugs for you!) and let them make some noise!
Copy.Pstm33:
Sticking to a bedtime routine.

As your child gets older, they might be quite happy to go to bed on the whole, but there will be days where your little one feels he or she will be missing out on all the excitement - and they'll do their best to put off the inevitable.

If you're not sure how to handle it, check out our tips and tricks to help you to keep to bedtime routines.
Copy.Pstm34:
Getting ready for your child's third birthday.

If you're having a birthday bash for your toddler, it's a good idea to get the invites out now, whether it's a small family gathering or something rather more costly. This year is probably the first year your child will truly understand what's happening and can enjoy the anticipation as well as the day.

This month, find out how to perform CPR - it's always best to be prepared. We've also got hints and tips on planning your family holiday, along with our travel safety kit advice so you'll be fully prepared to treat any minor ailments as soon as they happen.
Copy.Pstm35:
How to cope with biting, hitting and kicking.

If your little one has taken up biting, kicking or hitting you or other children, don't panic. Most toddlers go through an aggressive phase and the way you react will teach them that it is wrong and not to do it in the future. Don't be tempted to do the same back to them. Instead stay calm and follow our advice and they will soon be back to their sweet little selves in no time.

Pre-schoolers learn by playing rather than sitting down with workbooks. Introduce numbers into their playtime such as counting the number of steps and read to them daily using expressions and silly voices to make it fun and to get them to join in.
